intro.description: With ever-increasing data rates from multiple recording systems it is easy for an analysis plot to become swamped. Debrief NG provides tools to reduce the volume and type of data displayed. This tutorial will lead you through the management of large volumes of data.

item.title: Check you have some data
item.description: In the top left hand corner of Debrief you should find the Navigator window. If is isn't there, select "Navigator" from Debrief's Window/Show View menu. We're going to be working with the Sample.xml data-file from Debrief's sample data distribution. If you can't see the sample data, refer to the online help covering how to find/load it.

item.title: Open a sample file
item.description: Now double-click on Sample.xml in the navigator window. Our sample Debrief plot should now open

item.title: Check you can view the data
item.description: To be sure you can see all of the data, perform a fit-to-window operation, either via the Fit-to-Window button on the toolbar, or by the Fit-to-window button on the Chart Overview panel.

item.title: Open the Layer Manager
item.description: Next, make sure the Layer Manager is visible. Remember if any screen component it isn't visible you just load it by selecting it from the 'Window/Show View' menu.

item.title: Hide shape
item.description: In the layer manager, expand the layer titled "Misc (xx items)". After selecting an annotation from within that layer, click on the empty rectangle (next to the tick-in-rectangle). You should see the green tick disappear, together with the shape on the plot. Show the shape again - but this time use the Layer Manager drop-down menu (at the right of the Layer Manager's toolbar). (Note that you can hide/reveal more than one item at a time by holding down the control key to perform a multiple selection.)

item.title: Hide whole layer
item.description: Next, experiment with hiding whole layers: select one of the tracks in the Layer Manager and try hiding and revealing it. Note, that you can expand each track to see the series of positions inside it. Once expanded, you can select a series of point (representing a time-period) to be hidden/revealed. But hey, there are quicker ways than that - just keep reading.

item.title: Show Time Controller
item.description: Now we're going to filter the plot to a particular period of time. Start off by selecting the Time Controller (or opening it if it isn't already visible). The lower section of the time controller is a pair of sliders used to mark the start and end time of a variety of tasks.

item.title: Select Filter to Period
item.description: Instruct Debrief that we want the plot to be filtered according to the selected time period by selecting "Filter to period" from the Time Controller's drop-down menu. You'll also see a toggle button representing this action on the Time Controller's toolbar.

item.title: Trim visible time period
item.description: Now, as you drag the start and stop markers, the amount of data visible on the plot will be trimmed. Nice.
